posts.cooked:
APPLICATION “HAVEN” USING SIGNAL PROTOCOL FOR MESSAGING

The main idea, you leave laptop in hotel room and on top of laptop you leave secondary phone with Haven application that triggers when it recognizes the intruder. If this happens you can get a notification using Signal message to your primary phone. You have a serious baby sitting application that actually surveillance your belongings.

Citations from todays web news sites. You should read whole articles if interested in details.

THE INTERCEPT
Here’s how Haven might work: You lock your laptop in a hotel safe — not a secure move on its own — and place your Haven phone [my comment: This is ordinary phone with Haven application installed] on top of it. If someone opens the safe while you’re away, the phone’s light meter might detect a change in lighting, its microphone might hear the safe open (and even the attacker speak), its accelerometer might detect motion if the attacker moves the laptop, and its camera might even capture a snapshot of the attacker’s face. The Haven app will log all of this evidence locally on the Android device.

GUARDIAN PROJECT
integrated support for sending fully end-to-end encrypted notifications, with photo and audio attachments, over Signal. This method allows you to use a device without a SIM card, or in airplane mode, since Signal utilizes the internet for communication, not the mobile operator network.

It runs on any hardware that can support the Android operating system back to version 4.1. This includes not just smartphones, but also tablets, Raspberry Pi’s, TV set top boxes and sticks, and the emerging Android Things platform.

Most importantly, all network communications can be encrypted using other open-source gold standards such as Signal and Tor.

WIRED
But Haven takes some serious measures to prevent its surveillance mechanisms from being turned against a phone’s owner. It integrates the encrypted messaging app Signal, so that every alert, photo, and audio clip it sends to the user is end-to-end encrypted.

Movilizatorio founder Juliana Uribe Villegas says the app provided a key reassurance that month, for a group of 60 testers, that government or criminals agents weren’t breaking into their homes to plant surveillance equipment or, far worse, to kidnap or physically harm them.

EWEEK.COM
Among the software libraries used by Have is the libsignal-service-java from OpenWhisper System which provides a secure library for communicating with the Signal messaging service. Signal is a secure messaging app that Snowden has also recommended.

OFFICIAL PROJECT WEB SITE
Official Haven project web site and source code for the Haven project.

Snowden’s New App Uses Your Smartphone To Physically Guard Your Laptop
Snowden-Backed App 'Haven' Turns Your Phone Into a Home Security System | WIRED

GitHub - guardianproject/haven: Haven is for people who need a way to protect their personal spaces and possessions without compromising their own privacy, through an Android app and on-device sensors

posts.name: Nicholas Rizzio
posts.cooked: Haven uses Signal-CLI by AsamK! It’s nice to see 3rd party community contributions being used like this.

Haven looks quite exciting, I’ve been trying to setup something similar, and it is really frustrating - there are bunch of tools for the similar purpose - but they’re either non-free or closed source or rely on trusting 3rd party servers or require extra HW. Setting it up with existing reliable tools is definitely possible, but it has been a real PITA to manage.
So it’s really nice see a package like this coming out

From bellow article: “Snowden recommended using encrypted messaging app Signal, an app he says he uses every day.”

Snowden: Telegram Messenger App is Unsafe. Here’s Why

posts.cooked:
WIRED – 10 Jan 18

WhatsApp Flaws Could Allow Snoops to Slide Into Group Chats

German researchers say that a flaw in the app's group-chat feature undermines its end-to-end encryption promises.

link_counts.title: WhatsApp Encryption Security Flaws Could Allow Snoops to Slide Into Group Chats | WIRED

posts.cooked:
@anon57494327, thanks for the article. From above article recap: Security problems in WhatsApp only in group conversations if someone gets control of WhatsApp servers. There is no flaw in WhatsApp one-to-one conversation.

Just few highlights from article above:

WhatsApp group vulnerability
They say that anyone who controls WhatsApp’s servers could effortlessly insert new people into an otherwise private group, even without the permission of the administrator who ostensibly controls access to that conversation.

Group vulnerability in Signal too, but almost impossible to break
They warn that Signal allows the same group chat attack as WhatsApp, letting uninvited eavesdroppers join groups. But in Signal’s case, that eavesdropper would have to not only control the Signal server, but also know a virtually unguessable number called the Group ID. That essentially blocks the attack

For extremely sensitive group conversations use Signal until WhatApps fixes the problem
Until they do, WhatsApp’s most sensitive users should consider sticking with one-to-one conversations, or switching to a more secure group messaging app like Signal.

For details, please read whole article.
So where Group ID is stored?
